terms.definition: Product Requirements Document - an internal document that outlines what a product should accomplish for users without defining specific implementation details
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides self-service support to users
Unique Selling Points - distinctive features or benefits that differentiate a product from competitors in the market
A lightweight markup language that uses plain text formatting syntax to create structured documents with headings, lists, and links
Search Engine Optimization - the practice of optimizing content to improve visibility and ranking in search engine results
Search Engine Results Pages - the pages displayed by search engines in response to a user's query
Enhanced search results that display additional information like ratings, prices, or structured data beyond the standard title and description
User Interface - the visual elements and interactive components through which users interact with a software application
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code, allowing teams to collaborate and maintain different versions
Customer Experience - the overall perception and interaction a customer has with a company's products, services, and support
Keep It Simple, Stupid - a design principle emphasizing simplicity and avoiding unnecessary complexity in products or documentation
A readability test that scores text based on sentence length and syllable count to determine the education level needed to understand it
The consistent personality, style, and emotional quality expressed in written communication that reflects a brand's character
The process of adapting content, software, or products to meet the language, cultural, and regulatory requirements of specific markets
Brief HTML attributes that summarize a webpage's content and appear in search engine results below the page title
